title: Do you think Donald Trump is a bad leader? - Quora
tags: Politics of the United States of America

response.answer_text: A good leader leads by example; Donald Trump fires people who follow his example. A good leader takes responsibility for both his and his people’s actions; Donald Trump has never taken responsibility for anything in his life. A good leader inspires loyalty and respect from his troops; Donald Trump’s troops badmouth him behind his back at every turn. A good leader inspires with positivity; Donald Trump employs fear, hostility, and divisiveness. A good leader is a good judge of character; 40% of Trump’s cabinet have had ethics scandals, with no fewer than 11 open ethics investigations on his EPA administrator alone. A good leader demonstrates loyalty to his people; Donald Trump is loyal to no one, publicly attacking or firing the moment someone displeases him. A good leader empowers his people, delegating authority and supporting their decisions; Donald Trump routinely undercuts his people, criticizing, over-ruling, and publicly contradicting them. A good leader praises in public and criticizes in private; Donald Trump savagely criticizes, publicly berates, and revels in their humiliation. A good leader encourages cooperation and teamwork; Donald Trump foments rivalries and back-stabbing. His administration has been described as “a circular firing squad.” A good leader listens to his team’s advice and makes them feel heard; Donald Trump is notorious for ignoring his team’s advice. His team leaks to the media just to get his attention and feel heard. A good leader shares credit with his team; Donald Tump bristles at others sharing credit and fires those who dare to diminish his share of it. A good leader values honest feedback; Donald Trump demands sycophancy and punishes truth-telling. A good leader learns from his mistakes; Donald Trump makes the same mistakes again and again. A good leader puts the country ahead of himself; Donald Trump is profiting off the presidency. A good leader models strong work ethic for his employees; Donald Trump spends most mornings watching TV at home and has spent a third of his term at resorts, three times as many vacation days as his predecessor. A good leader communicates his positions clearly; Donald Trump regularly contradicts his own statements seconds after making them. President Eisenhower said, “The supreme quality of leadership is unquestionably integrity”; Donald Trump has told more than 3,000 documented lies since taking office, averaging about 6.5 public lies per day. A good leader consults key stakeholders before announcing big decisions; Donald Trump typically blindsides his own staff and allies with major changes in policy. A good leader is a reliable partner their allies can count on; Donald Trump constantly surprises and undercuts his own allies, even those carrying out his previous wishes. A good leader has the humility to admit they aren’t perfect; Donald Trump is incapable of admitting fault. A good leader has the humility to admit when they’re wrong; Donald Trump never admits when he’s wrong. Perhaps the only regret he admits is hiring Jeff Sessions. A good leader plans well into the future, even sacrificing short term gains to do so; Donald Trump lives entirely for the short term and is utterly beholden to his whims, a slave to impulse and emotion. A good leader hires in large part based on competence and integrity; Donald Trump hires based on nepotism and personal loyalty. A good leader avoids setting up his subordinates for failure; Donald Trump tasked his inexperienced son-in-law with government reform, fixing the opioid crisis, criminal justice reform, Muslim outreach, diplomacy with Mexico, diplomacy with China…and Middle East peace. A good leader holds themselves to a higher standard; Donald Trump explicitly holds himself to lower ethical standards than his employees have to, and brags about it. A good leader is engaged, focused on the problem at hand; Donald Trump can’t stay on topic, his meetings and calls with staff and allies meander far afield from topic, he interrupts conversations to bring up his electoral vote or the Russia investigation, his intelligence briefers make heavy use of pictures and his name to keep his attention. A good leader has the character to give close associates bad news personally; Donald Trump fires people via Tweet, via letter, via TV, or via delegate, never personally. A good leader abhors and avoids yes-men; Donald Trump surrounds himself with them, basking in their fawning obsequiousness. A good leader is in control of their emotions; Donald Trump is controlled by his emotions. A good leader considers their words carefully; Donald Trump…is Donald Trump. A good leader exhibits maturity and an ability to be the bigger person in difficult situations; Donald Trump is never the bigger person (figuratively speaking). A good leader brings out the best in people; Donald Trump brings out the worst. A good leader wants the best for his people; Donald Trump damages the futures of all who work for him. A good leader treats people with respect; Donald Trump insults people’s wives, parents, appearance, etc. A good leader adapts well to new information; Donald Trump resists it, ignoring inconvenient facts, findings, data, developments, etc. A good leader does not have their mental fitness questioned; Donald Trump’s has been called into serious question by dozens of mental health professionals. A good leader leaves the bragging about their personal qualities to others most of the time; Donald Trump calls himself the best everything and a “stable genius”. A good leader lets his doctor speak truthfully on his behalf; Donald Trump dictated his own medical report. A good leader’s lawyer does not need to pronounce he can’t be indicted; Donald Trump’s lawyer just did. A good leader’s speeches to civic groups are never a bad idea; Donald Trump’s led to an apology from the Boy Scouts for inviting him. A good leader’s publicly stated policy positions are not reversed lightly; Donald Trump’s positions are often reversed within days or hours. A good leader has few run-ins with the law, if any; Donald Trump has had many. A good leader has few criminal associates; Donald Trump has many. A good leader has no mob connections; Donald Trump has quite a few. A good leader has no need to praise murderous dictators; Donald Trump praises basically all of them. We could do this all day… Suffice to say, the distance between Donald Trump and admirable leadership is astronomical.

ALL ROADS LEAD TO RUSSIA!  Not only is Trump a bad leader, he is an asset of Russia, Turkey, and Iran… probably North Korea, and Israel is mixed up with it too. Trump, William Barr, Mike Pompeo, Rudy Giuliani, Mulvaney, Pence, Mannuchin, all of his family members are compromised! Also, Moscow Mitch and his GOP thugs are all corrupt, brainwashed or plain old stupid! I don’t know how any normal person can possibly keep up with the speed in which corruption schemes are being uncovered! I need a freaking map in my living room with Putin in the middle… and lines connecting all the “players”! It’s like a Mob Takedown! Our National Security has been comprised so badly, that it is breathtaking! I’m sure Mueller was aware of a lot of this, but felt he had to keep his mouth shut… either because he was aware of ongoing intelligence investigations, and/or he knew it was so bad, that he feared that Trump would take down The USA with him. So here we are… with a deranged, frightened, narcissist who’s finally getting backed into a corner called “THE Fu@&$ING TRUTH”. I pray to God that we rise from the ashes, ready to root out the kind of corruption that has decayed our institutions, and helped cause the apathy that has kept us from keeping a good eye on our elected officials, and allowed Russia to hack into our elections. Putin is laughing his head off! I’m sure he finds the “slow motion” implosion of our country very entertaining! A revolution is due! A new order by the people, for the people, is coming! Trump represents absolute evil. So much so, and so obviously, that it doesn’t seem real! Think about it… he has dismantled everything, from the environment, to our food, to our health care, to faith in our elections, to women’s rights, gun laws, our Allies no longer trust us, and now he hands our friends the Kurds over to slaughter. Haven’t enough red lines been crossed? The train is out of control, and we are about to jump the tracks! Trying to make some kind of sense of this… Perhaps Trump was the Miracle we needed to save ourselves and the world! You better hope so… otherwise, the Anti-Christ is running our country. High Crimes! Unstable insanity! Mitch… a piece of advice! Stand up, stand together with the House! Do your DUTY, and defend our country! Get Rid Of Trump! Nancy… Go put your white suit on, and like Joan of Arc, kick some ass!  Felt the need to ask WH if this is actually real and it is. pic.twitter.com/bHyIFw6cvO— Katie Rogers (@katierogers) October 16, 2019

To decide if someone is a good leader I would like to check some leadership attributes[1]: Be accountable: Trump showed over and over again that he refuses to take responsibility for his actions. He went bankrupt 4 times and needed to be bailed out by his dad and by not paying taxes. Whenever he is confronted with something he said that does make him look bad now, he denies or goes to his “I don’t know” answer. Be decisive: As said before his typical answers are: Yes, no I don’t know, some say, I guess so. The only thing he keeps up is that he wants to build a wall and that is a very weak message. Integrity: He cheated on his wives, he is the biggest name caller in the history of name calling, he used money from his charity foundation to pay for pictures of himself and to bribe officials, he did not pay taxes, he openly is proud how he buys officials, and he cheated on about every contractor who ever worked for him and this list is far from being complete. Focus: Well I don’t know, some say but we really should…. His policies are all over the place. He says one thing then the other and while the overall direction points towards a xenophobic racist point of view, the only focal point is the wall. Courage: Or as the German army said, lead from the front. He was a draft dodger. He only risked the capital of his dad and his investors. He followed the business of his dad, not trying something new. When asked what he sacrificed he said he created jobs….. Vision: He wants to make America great again, but this is not a vision, this is just a statement that America sucks. A vision needs to have a goal. A great vision came from JFK: By the end of the decade we will bring a man to the moon and back. This is actionable and time bound while “make America great again” has nothing actionable and is not time bound. It is like saying I like motherly love and apple pie. Humility: I think there is no argument about how humble the Donald is. Strategic Thinking: This might be a point where the Donald actually does not fail but does not score great either. But as we saw multiple times he lacks the ability to prepare for debates. He is not a facts person. He as well was not able to hire a speechwriter for his wife that does not copy Michelle Obama’s speech, that on top does not fit his life at all….. Cooperation: Saying you are a people person does not make you a people person. He has showed over and over again that he will cheat his partners. His catchphrase is: “you are fired”. Who would like to work for Trump if another Job would pay you the same? He publicly told: “When I negotiate, they lose and I win.” A good deal means both win and when you know the other side wants you to lose, you are not willing to make a fair and beneficial deal. Now this is all independent of where Trump wants the country to be. [1] 7 Leadership Qualities and Attributes of Great Leaders | Brian Tracyhttp://www.briantracy.com/blog/leadership-success/the-seven-leadership-qualities-of-great-leaders-strategic-planning/

Trump is a less than ideal leader because he fails at both parts of leadership, which isn’t easy to do. He doesn’t lead, he follows. When he does decide to lead he doesn’t care what anyone else thinks, does what he wants and tells people to get on board or get out, while they thought they were already on board. (If you are asking about how Trump leads people who don’t work for him I would give a different answer.) Part of the problem with leadership is that the leader is in charge. If you have a better idea the leader still gets his way. A bad leader doesn’t give enough respect or power to his underlings - so the leader is stuck with the whole job of leading - because he didn’t lead his own crew better. That kind of leader will make a snap decision and roll with it. When things are not disastrous it ‘proves’ the leader right, so he thinks he is an awesome leader. We will never know if the other ideas would have worked even better. This way may be better than a leader who is so busy listening to everyone that he can’t act decisively, but really you don’t want either of those guys in charge. You want the leader who gathers experts, hears their advice, decides what to do, and tells his people what he wants done. Another example of poor leadership is a lack of clarity in his instructions. This may be the most important thing. We should never hear Trump contradict the State Department, especially on twitter. Top lieutenants should know what the leader wants and then carry it out. He should have been running State better, or he should be listening to his experts. It sounds like one of a few things happened there. Maybe he didn’t give the State department a clear enough idea about what he wants them to do. Maybe he decided to listen to someone other than the State Department without consulting or informing them of his decision before telling the whole world. Maybe he changed his mind and didn’t tell anyone. Maybe they gave him what he asked for, and when he saw it he didn’t like it and blamed his people rather than admit he didn’t give clear guidance. No matter what, Trump should have people he delegates to run things the way he wants them run. If they aren’t running it that way, is it because the person refuses to obey the president? Is it because they are unable to perform the job? It is more likely because the president didn’t tell the people who work for him what he is thinking, so they had no way of knowing how he wants things done. It is much easier to work for a general than it is to work for a captain. The general is really really good at giving orders and seeing that they are carried out. The captain might not be quite as mentally organized - he is more likely to delegate tasks without clarity and then wonder why no one can do what he wants. The general delegates responsibility and his people know what to do and do it. People who work for the captain can only try. (I have only worked with military people who retired - I don’t want to imply that I served). Another problem is that Trump isn’t always a leader. He is a follower way too often. I think it is hard to deny that his image means a lot to him. If he finds out that people believe a certain way he will say something to please them or to denigrate them-whichever his followers will like best. If something will make people, especially his supporters, like him more then he does it. There needs to be a balance. You don’t want a leader who isn’t paying attention to the people. You don’t want a leader who just does whatever is popular. It seems like we have the latter with Trump. We have a Vegas massacre and a lot of school shootings, and Trump talks about raising the purchase age for guns to 21 and banning bump stocks, because a lot of people wanted something done about it. The next day Trump’s donors and supporters are quite upset with those ideas, and he immediately reverses course. There are right ways to do these things. He could have consulted his people first, who would have told him that he better talk to the NRA before considering new gun laws. Or he could have stuck to his position and told the NRA ‘I’m still better than Clinton’. Instead he followed, and then followed again. Trump gives us a disturbing combination of these. He won’t take advice, won’t respect the people he delegates authority to, and changes his mind. How does anyone work for people like that?

I believe that Trump is not a good leader because nearly everything he says and does is terrible and if all Americans did as he does there would be more unemployment, poverty and misery, not to mention more discord among countries around the world. Nearly everyone knows his flaws, even if they don’t care about them, but I will list the worst ones: He lies constantly. Whether he is even aware he is doing it is conjecture because it is unrelenting, even as far as denying he said something that there is a video of him saying. That his followers don’t care about this is terrifying to me.He verbally attacks those whom he feels “aren’t nice” to him, even after decades have passed. What could that turn into? He encourages his followers to attack his detractors. He wants his followers to police voting precincts and intimidate voters who might vote against him.He doesn’t care about the country. If the US were bombed to smithereens he is rich enough to pack up and move to Russia. Don’t think he wouldn’t. He only wants to be president to improve his business dealings. He has no intention of doing the work himself.He doesn’t care about the rest of the world. He wants to dump NATO, evidently on the urging of his Russian friends. He thinks more countries should have nuclear weapons. He doesn’t know what a nuclear winter is. If Trump is elected, the doomsday clock will move closer to human annihilation than it has ever been.

I believe Trump’s tweet over the weekend about the Democrats being to blame for the immigrant children who have now been “lost” in the system is an excellent example of why he is not a good leader. A good leader does not point fingers and then sit back and do nothing. He has been blaming Democrats for his legislative failures for the last 15 months. But the Democrats hold absolutely no power. They control nothing in Washington. When Trump is not blaming the Democrats, he’s blaming the media or the intelligence community. This is not a trait of a good leader. In addition, he spends a tremendous amount of time watching Fox News, sending out tweets, and playing golf. (The amount of golf he plays is orders of magnitude higher than Obama, whom Trump criticized for playing too much golf.) Our nation is deeply divided, along political, racial, and ideological lines. A good leader would be focused on that. A good leader would be doing something more than paying lip service to those concerned about gun violence, while praising the NRA. A good leader would not tear up international agreements without having another solution firmly in hand. Finally, it is my opinion that a good leader is not a bully. A good leader doesn’t call people names and accuse them of being liars when he disagrees with them. A good leader doesn’t change his mind from one day to the next, or sometimes even one hour to the next. A good leader is decisive, but a good leader also listens to those around him are more expert than he in certain matters. On a less objective note, I believe a good leader reads and is knowledgeable about the history of the organization he is supposed to be leading, as well as other relevant history. I also believe a good leader does not abuse his power to punish his enemies. Case in point, Trump’s pressuring the Postmaster General to increase rates on Amazon because Jeff Bezos owns The Washington Post, despite the fact that the U.S. Postal Service has a contract with Amazon. So, those are some reasons I think Trump is not a good leader. Unless, of course, your question was meant to ask why Trump is incapable of being a good leader. In that case, the answer is simple: A good leader has to consider what’s good for other people besides just himself.

Thanks for the A2A. The current President of the United States assumed office on 20th January 2017: a little more than a month ago. His administration is not even in place yet: a number of senior level positions have yet to be filled. There is the inevitable confusion and uncertainty that accompanies such a transition. So he hasn’t really had time to rule yet. There is no way of judging the quality of his administration. The American system gives each President a 4 year term (extendable to at most another 4 years). That is the time scale over which to judge performance. So something like 2 years into the administration would be a good point to start making judgements. However, Mr. Trump is not your usual politician. In fact, he is not a politician in the conventional sense. He did not work his way up the machinery of the existing political parties, building networks of support and funds, cultivating constituencies etc. Mr. Trump is very much like some character played by Salman Khan (think Chulbul Pandey). Rude, boastful, self-assured. Do you remember that scene in Dabang where the priest asks who will bless Chulbul’s wedding? When no one steps forward, Chulbul Pandey blesses himself. Mr. Trump’s attitude is a lot like that. He doesn’t need anybody. Not their support, not their money. Nothing. He is his own man. The current political establishment (including the resource intensive mainstream media) is deeply threatened by such a man. He has no use for the deep, tight and complex web of relationships, quid pro quos and money channels that they have set up over the decades: definitely in their own interest and not necessarily in the interest of the general population. They thought they had the power game locked up. Mr. Trump has smashed through their illusions. Like some ancient champion, he has performed a feat of might and ability. Quite literally glorious to behold. All the protests about poor administrative quality etc is just wishful thinking. The established elite wish he would be a poor administrator. That is the only way they can recover their power and influence (which is, of course, wealth). If he turns out to be great administrator, they will be utterly discredited. What you are seeing is a remarkable, even historical, transition of real power where one group of elites is supplanted by another. The old group is not going out without a fight. Note: While this is fun to watch (who doesn’t enjoy seeing on fat cats’ tails get stepped on?) it need not necessarily be better for the general population. It is merely an exchange of elites. It is not guaranteed that the new elite will be more in touch with the common man than the old.

In every company I’ve worked for, it’s not just about results, it’s about how you achieve them. In every single company I’ve worked for: A CEO who gets the same results as the last CEO, but has a revolving door for a staff , would not last long, if he’d even be selected for the job in the first place. A CEO who talks a big game but prioritizes making himself look good over the good of the company, would not last long. A CEO who focuses on ineffective policies like building a stupid and expensive wall, would not last long. A CEO who gleefully alienates half the company (e.g. “I’m a finance guy so to hell with those stupid sales and marketing people”) would not last long, or likely even be hired in the first place. A CEO who is the subject of every story he tells, who constantly boasts about how great he is, who makes up facts and figures to prove to everyone how great he is, would not be selected for the job in the first place. A CEO who constantly whines and complains about our competitors would not even get the job in the first place. A CEO who had done well on reality TV but otherwise had a poor track record for business would not even get the job in the first place. A CEO who has declared bankruptcy 6 times, and would essentially fail a background check, would not even get the job in the first place. Would any company hire Trump to run it? Would anyone trust Trump and his family with the keys to the company and trust him to steward that company and its brand, to take great care of its customers, and guide the company into the future? None of the companies, including several in the Fortune 500, would, because they care about the how as much as the what. Is something wrong with them? Would you even trust Trump to run a department at your company, and if so, which one, and why?

If you voted for candidate Trump as an FU to The Man, as someone who would lead an antiEstablishment wave in Washington, DC, you got took, as we say down here in Tennessee. But if you are a member of The Establishment he’s been a good leader. The Establishment has gotten just about everything on their wish list. There’s a few things they’re still looking for and the Trump Administration is working on those wishes yet to be fulfilled, but the fix is in. If you are still looking for the antiEstablishment leader you voted for, well, don’t hold your breath. You’ll have to be happy with Trump’s unconventional and often outrageous behavior, because that’s all your going to get. You’re not going to get any deconstruction of The Establishment, it has been and is going to be further enriched. So the answer to this question depends on whether you’re a member of The Establishment or not. If you are then President Trump is a good leader. If you aren’t he’s not. Of course, millions of Trump voters haven’t figured this out yet. And many of them never will.

YES i think he is 1 of the best LEADERS!!! He knows what he wants like nobody else, he has his own way of doing thinks not like other presidents who are doing the same failing things for decades, 1. like his trade deals policies he is thinking of the american worker. 2. and like NATO where he is demanding from all our partners to pay their fair share. 3. on security he is not afraid to confront RADICAL ISLAMIC TERRORISM and tell openly to our Muslim partners that they need to stop their extremist. 4. he is connecting to the working class people in america like nobody else and no matter how hostile the MEDIA is to him they are still loyal to each other. 5. look at the trip he is taking now the the MIDDLE EAST , i have never seen an american leader get this kind of respect of other leaders, it’s on real the respect he is receiving from the Muslim leaders, because they know he is a leader and he is not afraid from nobody. 6. he understands things like nobody else look how many people dismissed him THE MEDIA, THE NEVER TRUMPERS, THE REPUBLICAN ESTABLISHMENT, THE DEMOCRATS, and every time he won, and he had a clearer vision then all of them. i need to leave it here although i have much more examples of his leadership skills, THANK YOU ALL FOR READING MY ANSWER I HOPE YOU WILL GIVE ME AN UP-VOTE, THANKS AGAIN.

Mostly worse than bad, in my opinion. Leaders need to have a defined goal, a coherent plan to reach that goal, and intelligent, skilled and motivated people around them for support. A leader MUST be trusted, and he must be willing to trust his inner circle…even when they tell him something he doesn’t want to hear. Does any of the above sound like Trump to you? As my late husband used to say back in his military days, “I wouldn’t follow him to the bathroom out of curiosity!”

I think perhaps you, and Little Donny, are confused. The United States is a Democratic Republic, NOT at monarchy or dictatorship. Little Donny is a bad LEADER, he is NOT the USA’s ruler. And never will be.

Why? Because Trump views himself as a 'ruler' and not as a leader. The term 'ruler' suggests complete control without the help, assistance or collaboration from anyone else. Surely having a 'leader' would be more desirable? "A ruler owns his subjects. Meaning they're accountable to him/her but he/she isn't accountable to them. A leader is someone that carries a collective from one point to another. For example, one can lead someone to prosperity the same way you can lead someone into poverty. Both are leaders because they are the prime navigators. A ruler, then, is an owner and a leader is a driver. A leader is only an authority because a collective has chosen to follow their path but a ruler moves the collective where they see fit as his/her property". Donald Trump has taken his position as president and abused it. His actions are much like a dictator. He taunts the leader of North Korea, Kim Jong-un because he is a dictator and rules his country as an autocracy, but does Trump really behave that differently? He appears to fire anyone who stands up to him and anyone who stands in his way. He smears and slanders anyone who wants to take a different approach to him or who questions his policies. I have no doubt that if it were legal he would imprison them too. He continues to attempt to ban the movement of people traveling from certain Muslim majority countries to the US despite this action being ruled against in federal court (this shows complete disregard and contempt for the rule of law while illustrating the lengths he will go to in order to get his way) He also wants to build a wall between Mexico and the US. Both of these actions effectively creates and 'them and us' scenario, isolating 'his' country and 'his' people from anyone and anything that HE deems a threat to HIS ideals. Surely both these actions are something that should be voted on by the people? Isn't that the democratic way? He is a man gone mad with power, and absolute power corrupts absolutely! Trump most certainly behaves like a ruler, and that alone is what makes him "bad". Trump is as close to a dictator than any other president in history and the only thing that stops him from 'ruling' absolutely is the democracy within the constitution!

Interesting wording of the question. Most have answered why Trump is a “bad leader,” but (unless the question has been changed) you ask “Why is Trump considered a bad ruler?” I have never thought of any of the previous 44 POTUSes as “rulers.” Perhaps, as far as “rulers” are concerned, he would not be considered a bad one. If he had full authoritarian power, as most rulers have had, perhaps he would have been as good as Castro, Stalin, Hitler, Noriega or any of the other nefarious rulers we know of. He is a bad ruler because our Constitution doesn’t permit rulers. Instead, as much as Trump would like to think otherwise, he is stuck being a mere Executive, whose powers are supposed to be equal to the Legislative and Judicial Branches. The other difference between the POTUS and a ruler is the President works for the people, not the other way around.

Yes. I think he is an example of the worst of our human nature. He is the embodiment of unchecked greed, racism, bigotry, sexism, lack of compassion, and a callous disregard for our fellow man. I think he is a grifter by nature and is fleecing the office for personal gain. I think he has torn our unity beyond repair and destroyed what patriotism means and bastardized it with a form of nationalistic fervor on par with 1930s Germany. I think that history will not be kind to this era because of him and those that align themselves with him.

Effective leaders are made over time with practice, discipline, love and patience. Trump practiced dirty dealing. He practicing being a con all his life. Trump was disciplined by being sent away to a military boarding school where he continued to bully, boast and lie. Love has evaded Trump if failed marriages and failed affairs with porn stars are any indication. The tweets? Trump has about as much patience as a 2 year old, as the gratification he apparently gets from tweeting has to be often and immediate. …We all get it. Trump is a repulsive egomaniac driven by greed; a self-serving con. Its scary. Trump is not a good leader because Trump was bought. The 7 Characteristics of a Good Leader | Edutopia

I look forward to voting for this so called ‘bad leader' again. If a bad leader can axe hurtful regulations that drive business away with his pen, and offer tax relief to millions of overburdened Americans, all in his first year and a half, then sign me up for ‘bad leader'. I'm not even going to go into the economy… I guess since his tweets are so outrageous and un-Bush-like, that makes him a bad leader. I am looking forward to 6 1\2 more years of this Bad Leader!

He is a far better leader than any Socialist Democrat could ever hope to be. Trump has done a far better job than Obama ever did. Russia was not a thing. If it was we would see some kind of evidence after 3 years and hundreds of millions of dollars. They don’t want him impeached because he broke the law. Since he didn’t. They want him impeached because they can’t stand the idea of having a president who doesn’t bow down to Social Justice and Political Correctness.

How about the fact that he treats our allies like ex-wives? In his first week in office he got into shouting matches over the phone with Australia’s prime minister and Mexico’s president. Then he made up statistics about the U.S.-Canada trade deficit out of whole cloth, recited them to PM Justin Trudeau, and then bragged about lying to Trudeau? How about the fact that he’s always flip-flopping according to who was the last person who talked to him? How about his closest advisers: Ivanka, Jared, and Sean Hannity? How about his ever-shifting relationship with Vladimir Putin, but his consistent refusal to acknowledge that the Russians are trying to hack our voting machines? How about…oh, never mind. Pick anything he’s done since he was sworn in, and you can safely say it was the wrong thing.

Donald Trump doesn’t respect anyone but Donald Trump. He is convinced of his own intellect. At the same time, he is so insecure that he has to plaster his name on everything, tell all and sundry about how great he is, he lies about his achievements despite the fact his claims can be checked. He appoints subordinates who are more concerned with stroking his ego than giving him useful data, and he creates an environment that encourages those subordinates to be so busy backstabbing each other that nothing useful gets done. He has a vindictive streak a mile wide, and he lets it guide his decision making. He has no apparent understanding of or concern for the impact of his words and actions on others. He has spent his entire life being either the boss’ son or the boss. He has never had to actually deal with “No”. He’s used to making deals by being a loud, obnoxious bully.

Trump is not a ‘ruler’ at all; he holds elective office. His job is to enforce the true ruler in the US-the Constitution. What makes him a bad president? He doesn’t understand that he’s not a ruler. He thinks that loyalty to him is more important than loyalty to US law. He’s thin-skinned. He knows no history. He’s a habitual liar. I could go on all day.

The colonies that formed the United States of America got rid of the last ruler during the Revolutionary War. I am shocked that “We the People” were fooled (by Russia, by slogans like MAGA, by racism or by whatever) into voting into office a man who appears to believe that the President is a ruler. The President has a number of functions, as specified in the Constitution and clarified by Congress and the Judicial branch over the past 250+ years. Even Her Majesty, the Queen of England is no longer “a ruler” in the way King George was.

A leader is someone who has a vision of the future, a plan for achieving that vision and the means to persuade others to want to share in that vision. Trump can’t see further into the future that his next round of golf, he doesn’t have the intelligence to plan, and and he’s alienated and insulted too many people for them to want to take part in any action he might take.

Trump is not a ruler. He is President. This gives him a leadership role in the U.S. government whose limits are defined by law. The rulers in the U.S. are the people. The people that elected Trump could be considered poor rulers or at the very least credulous and misinformed.
Don’t think he is bad or stupid. But he is not suitable for playing the role of President of the United States. For the Trump Org, he is a good leader and builder. But it’s just not the same case.

Ruler? Why is he considered a bad ruler? See, this is the same delusion he has. He is not a ruler! He does not get to decide what does and does not happen in this, or any other, country. We live in a democracy, and bad mouth it all you want, there is still a rule of law here that says anything the president wants done has to be approved by Congress, at the very least AND that the laws of the land apply equally to him and his family as much as to anybody else. It is his choice to be ignorant of these facts – and it is a choice, he does know better – that is causing so much of what he is criticized for. He’s not a bad ruler. He’s not a ruler, though he is striving mightily to be.

I'm sure a lot of people will answer so instead of a long list (which I could certainly do) I will give you one big one. Leaders need to be consistent.
